HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 16, 1928

SENIOR CLASS WILL
MEET ON TUESDAY
Due to the small attendance
last Tuesday, the senior class
meeting scheduled for that
day has been postponed until
next Tuesday, March 20. All
seniors are urged to attend.
Several important matters
are to be brought up which
were not discussed at the last
meeting. These include the
matter of an honorary class
president and installments on
class dues, without the payment of which no senior will
get into the Hullabaloo. Matters pertaining to June Week
are also to be discussed.

SMITH LEADS HOOVER
IN POLL OF CAMPUS
New York Governor is Popular
Choice Among Students;
Ritchie Third
"Al" Smith's religion is not a
handicap in regard to his eligibility
as a presidential prospect. This is
attested by the fact that he has
eight votes more than any other
candidate in the NEWS - LETTER
straw vote contest being conducted
at the present. Hoover is running
a poor second, while Ritchie, the
logical choice of the people of
Maryland is barely third, his place
being closely contested by Lowden.

ALUMNI MEMORIAL
HALL GETS $10,000
Ten thousand dollars has
been donated to Alumni Memorial Hall by the widow of
the late W. Stuart Symington,
it was announced by Dean
Ames. The gift was made by
Mrs. Symington,in memory of
her husband and is to go to
the Hall fund.
It was also announced that
"Entry F" in the future will
be known as the W. Stuart
Symington entry. This is in
accordance with the plan recently adopted to name all entries in the Alumni Memorial
Hall after men who have been
benefactors to the University.
The Symington entry is the
first to be so named.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
As a trifling item which might
be of interest to the ladies (very
few of whom read this column,
however, we imagine) it was recently announced that out of the some
thousand and odd students at the
University of Maryland only four
succeeded in maintaining an average of A for the past semester. Of
this four it happened that exactly
one hundred per cent were members
of the fair sex.

Numerous excited comments and
queries were recently being passed
around the campus of the University of Kansas when thirty-one
pledges were officially detained by
the police while engaged in sonic of
those duties which are the necessary
elements of "hell week" or fraternity initiations. As a result the student council of the University has
filed a protest with the city officials
complaining against the drastic action.

A verbal chastisement was recently presented the student body of
Ohio Wesleyan by the faculty of
that institution. It seems as though
the students have been allowed so
much authority of late that they
have gone so far as to suggest that
they be allowed admittance to faculty proceedings.
The President
summed up the situation by rather
sarcastically stating that the .students were "too busy running the
University."

(

A petition of 116 students of Boston University was recently presented to the Dean, requesting that
bridge playing between classes
should be countenanced. The proposition was rejected in unqualified
terms as being both "dangerous and
unbusiness like." It seems as though
the drawback was in the fact that
fifty of the total number of petitioners had previously received
warning of being placed on scholastic probation.

The student council of the University of Akron are utilizing a
novel method of enforcing frosh
regulations. All freshmen found
guilty of disobeying any rules are
penalized by the complete loss of
their votes in class elections during
their first year.

A Leap Year party was the latest
at the University of Miami last
week when the coeds held a party
for men students on the 29th of
February. The young ladies arranged for their engagements,
called for their dates, and escorted
them home after the dance.

The honor system of examinations at Yale will be abolished and
faculty supervision reinstated as a
result of a recent questionnaire on
the advisabilityof continuance of the
system. Although only one-half of
the total membership of the three
upper classes cast votes, 148 balloted as being opposed to the present system. Two hundred and
sixty-three voters favored a continuance of the practice as then
in force while 361 voted in favor
of no supervision of any kind.
While the majority of those voting
were in favor of some form of
honor system, it was pointed out
that this number was a small portion of the entire student body and
that a more nearly unanimous number would be needed for a satisfactory enforcement. Apathy of the
students and their unwillingness to
report violations were given by the
student council as their reasons for
urging abolition of the system.

a half a couple will be the fee
for admission.

staged by the club, which has
not been long on the caMpus.

All Roles in "The Champion"
Are Definitely Assigned
All speaking parts in the 1928
production, "The
Barnstormer
Champion," have been definitely
assigned. Those who will play the
most important roles have been decided on for some time, but it was
not until this week that the entire
cast was definitely chosen.
Those in the cast whose names
have not been published before are:
Jane Burroughs—R. Rothschild.
David Burroughs—R. Berney.
Simmons—Dal Strader.
Mr. Coykendall—W.W.McDowell.
Earl of Chuffleigh—I. K. Gordon.
Marquis of Harroween—J. Clarke.
Baron Halloway—G. Farinholt.
Mayor of Knotley--S. M. Powell.
Frank Smith—J. Deets.
In addition to the above, "Benny"
Boynton will take the lead as the
Champion, while R. Jones, White,
Warfield, D. Horn, W. B. Banks,
Caplan and Natt also have important parts.
It is interesting to note the interest that members of the football
team are taking in the play. Three
varsity men have important parts in
the play, while one, Boynton, is to
play the lead. Quite a bit of interest is being shown in the role of
Antoinette, the French maid, being
played by the Jay halfback, Caplan.
Business Manager Douglas Prahl
decried the lack of interest being
shown in the ticket contest. The
idea in staging the contest, stated
Prahl, was to increase the ticket sale
and at the same time remunerate
those selling tickets. The campaign
will be discontinued if no more interest is shown.
Tickets go on sale at the Barn
Monday and will be sold every day
at noon from then until the first
performance. Tickets are $2.00,
$1.50 and $1.00.

Rabbi To Speak On
Hebrew Alphabet
Rabbi W. Willner, of Frederick,
Md., will address the local chapter
of the Avukah today at 12.30 in
Gilman 112. Rabbi Willner's lecture will be on the Hebrew alphabet
and is somewhat in the form of an
answer to Ittamar Ben Avi, the famous Hebrew publicist, who spoke
to the group several weeks ago.
Rabbi Willner is a Yale graduate, receiving his A. B. in 1885. He
received his M. A. in Romance Languages from Hopkins.
On March 28 the Hopkins chapter will debate the Washington
branch of the Avukah at the Mercantile Club. A musicale is being
arranged for the same evening.
NOTICES
Students interested in
the National Oratorical
Contest on the Constitution and sophomores who
wish to take part in the
Adams Medal Cimtest
should see Norman Gardiner at once.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 16, 1928

SENIOR CLASS WILL
MEET ON TUESDAY
Due to the small attendance
last Tuesday, the senior class
meeting scheduled for that
day has been postponed until
next Tuesday, March 20. All
seniors are urged to attend.
Several important matters
are to be brought up which
were not discussed at the last
meeting. These include the
matter of an honorary class
president and installments on
class dues, without the payment of which no senior will
get into the Hullabaloo. Matters pertaining to June Week
are also to be discussed.

SMITH LEADS HOOVER
IN POLL OF CAMPUS
New York Governor is Popular
Choice Among Students;
Ritchie Third
"Al" Smith's religion is not a
handicap in regard to his eligibility
as a presidential prospect. This is
attested by the fact that he has
eight votes more than any other
candidate in the NEWS - LETTER
straw vote contest being conducted
at the present. Hoover is running
a poor second, while Ritchie, the
logical choice of the people of
Maryland is barely third, his place
being closely contested by Lowden.

ALUMNI MEMORIAL
HALL GETS $10,000
Ten thousand dollars has
been donated to Alumni Memorial Hall by the widow of
the late W. Stuart Symington,
it was announced by Dean
Ames. The gift was made by
Mrs. Symington,in memory of
her husband and is to go to
the Hall fund.
It was also announced that
"Entry F" in the future will
be known as the W. Stuart
Symington entry. This is in
accordance with the plan recently adopted to name all entries in the Alumni Memorial
Hall after men who have been
benefactors to the University.
The Symington entry is the
first to be so named.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
As a trifling item which might
be of interest to the ladies (very
few of whom read this column,
however, we imagine) it was recently announced that out of the some
thousand and odd students at the
University of Maryland only four
succeeded in maintaining an average of A for the past semester. Of
this four it happened that exactly
one hundred per cent were members
of the fair sex.

Numerous excited comments and
queries were recently being passed
around the campus of the University of Kansas when thirty-one
pledges were officially detained by
the police while engaged in sonic of
those duties which are the necessary
elements of "hell week" or fraternity initiations. As a result the student council of the University has
filed a protest with the city officials
complaining against the drastic action.

A verbal chastisement was recently presented the student body of
Ohio Wesleyan by the faculty of
that institution. It seems as though
the students have been allowed so
much authority of late that they
have gone so far as to suggest that

A petition of 116 students of Boston University was recently presented to the Dean, requesting that
bridge playing between classes
should be countenanced. The proposition was rejected in unqualified
terms as being both "dangerous and
unbusiness like." It seems as though
the drawback was in the fact that
fifty of the total number of petitioners had previously received
warning of being placed on scholastic probation.

The student council of the University of Akron are utilizing a
novel method of enforcing frosh
regulations. All freshmen found
guilty of disobeying any rules are
penalized by the complete loss of
their votes in class elections during
their first year.

A Leap Year party was the latest
at the University of Miami last
week when the coeds held a party
for men students on the 29th of
February. The young ladies arranged for their engagements,
called for their dates, and escorted
them home after the dance.

The honor system of examinations at Yale will be abolished and
faculty supervision reinstated as a
result of a recent questionnaire on
the advisabilityof continuance of the
system. Although only one-half of
the total membership of the three
upper classes cast votes, 148 balloted as being opposed to the present system. Two hundred and
sixty-three voters favored a continuance of the practice as then
in force while 361 voted in favor
of no supervision of any kind.
While the majority of those voting
were in favor of some form of
honor system, it was pointed out
that this number was a small portion of the entire student body and
that a more nearly unanimous number would be needed for a satisfactory enforcement. Apathy of the
students and their unwillingness to
report violations were given by the
student council as their reasons for
urging abolition of the system.
CARROLL CLUB
DANCE TOMORROW
Tomorrow night the Charles
Carroll Club, the campus
Catholic organiation, will give
an informal dance in the C. E.
Hall. The affair will last from
nine till midnight, and music
will be supplied by the Blue
Jay orchestra. One dollar and
a half a couple will be the fee
for admission.
This dance is the first affair
staged by the club, which has
not been long on the caMpus.

All Roles in "The Champion"
Are Definitely Assigned
All speaking parts in the 1928
production, "The
Barnstormer
Champion," have been definitely
assigned. Those who will play the
most important roles have been decided on for some time, but it was
not until this week that the entire
cast was definitely chosen.
Those in the cast whose names
have not been published before are:
Jane Burroughs—R. Rothschild.
David Burroughs—R. Berney.
Simmons—Dal Strader.
Mr. Coykendall—W.W.McDowell.
Earl of Chuffleigh—I. K. Gordon.
Marquis of Harroween—J. Clarke.
Baron Halloway—G. Farinholt.
Mayor of Knotley--S. M. Powell.
Frank Smith—J. Deets.
In addition to the above, "Benny"
Boynton will take the lead as the
Champion, while R. Jones, White,
Warfield, D. Horn, W. B. Banks,
Caplan and Natt also have important parts.
It is interesting to note the interest that members of the football
team are taking in the play. Three
varsity men have important parts in
the play, while one, Boynton, is to
play the lead. Quite a bit of interest is being shown in the role of
Antoinette, the French maid, being
played by the Jay halfback, Caplan.
Business Manager Douglas Prahl
decried the lack of interest being
shown in the ticket contest. The
idea in staging the contest, stated
Prahl, was to increase the ticket sale
and at the same time remunerate
those selling tickets. The campaign
will be discontinued if no more interest is shown.
Tickets go on sale at the Barn
Monday and will be sold every day
at noon from then until the first
performance. Tickets are $2.00,
$1.50 and $1.00.

Rabbi To Speak On
Hebrew Alphabet
Rabbi W. Willner, of Frederick,
Md., will address the local chapter
of the Avukah today at 12.30 in
Gilman 112. Rabbi Willner's lecture will be on the Hebrew alphabet
and is somewhat in the form of an
answer to Ittamar Ben Avi, the famous Hebrew publicist, who spoke
to the group several weeks ago.
Rabbi Willner is a Yale graduate, receiving his A. B. in 1885. He
received his M. A. in Romance Languages from Hopkins.
On March 28 the Hopkins chapter will debate the Washington
branch of the Avukah at the Mercantile Club. A musicale is being
arranged for the same evening.

Donald White, editor-in-chief,
urged that the art and editorial
staffs co-operate with one another
nd with him so that the high standard and reputation of the magazine
be maintained.
The next issue, which is to be
released in time for the Barnstormers' production on Friday,
March 23, will be an "Intelligentsia
Theatre" number. In this issue,
White expects to have the Jay appropriate to the occasion, and at the
same time he hopes to get away
from the stereotyped "Barnstormer Number" which has been regularly coming out for the past few
years. The little theatre movement
will very likely be the butt of many
jests, and it is expected that the editors will make the conventional
quips about the characteristics of
the Barnstormer heroines.
The staffs at present are bending all their energies to the task
of getting editorial as well as advertising copy ready in time.
